episodeTitle: Revived Fate! Nami and the Fish-Man Pirates!
episodeTitleJapanese: 蘇る因縁！ナミと魚人海賊団！
episodeTitleRomanized: Yomigaeru In'nen! Nami to Gyojin Kaizoku-dan!
description: Robin discovers a mysterious Poneglyph in the Sea Forest while the New Fish-Man Pirates terrorize citizens. Nami confronts Jinbe about his connection to Arlong, leading to painful flashbacks and a revelation about Fish-Man Island's tragic history.

events.title: Robin Discovers Joy Boy's Poneglyph
events.description: Nico Robin finds a Poneglyph in the Sea Forest, believing it contains information about the Void Century. Upon reading it, she discovers it is an apology letter from Joy Boy to the ancient mermaid princess Poseidon for breaking his promise regarding the ship Noah.
events.significance: This is the first mention of Joy Boy in the series, a mysterious figure from the Void Century who will become crucial to understanding the world's history and Luffy's destiny. The apology letter hints at an ancient connection between Joy Boy and the mermaid kingdom.

quotes.speaker: Nico Robin
quotes.context: Robin reads the Poneglyph and realizes its unusual content

events.title: New Fish-Man Pirates Force Fumi-e Ritual
events.description: The New Fish-Man Pirates, led by Hyouzou, force Fish-Man Island citizens to step on a fumi-e (stepping picture) of the beloved Queen Otohime as a loyalty test. Citizens who refuse are threatened with death or exile from the island.
events.significance: This demonstrates the extremism of the New Fish-Man Pirates and their hatred for Otohime's ideals of peace between fish-men and humans. The historical reference to fumi-e, used to test Christians in feudal Japan, adds weight to this scene's cultural significance.

quotes.text: Either step on the fumi-e or get off the island. Otherwise, I'll cut you down.
quotes.speaker: Hyouzou
quotes.context: Hyouzou threatens citizens who hesitate to step on Queen Otohime's image

events.title: Nami Confronts Jinbe About Arlong
events.description: Nami directly asks Jinbe if he was responsible for sending Arlong to the East Blue. This confrontation brings Nami's painful past to the forefront as she seeks answers about why she and her village suffered for eight years under Arlong's tyranny.
events.significance: This moment connects the Fish-Man Island arc to Nami's traumatic backstory from the Arlong Park arc, showing how the actions of Fish-Man Island's residents have affected the Straw Hats personally. It sets up the flashback arc that will explain Jinbe's history with Arlong.

quotes.text: Did you send Arlong to the East Blue?
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami directly confronts Jinbe about his connection to her tormentor

quotes.text: Nami had it hard with Arlong for eight long years. What you say next will decide if I forgive you or not.
quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji protectively warns Jinbe about the weight of this conversation

events.title: Nami's Flashback to Arlong Park
events.description: Nami experiences flashbacks to her painful past under Arlong's rule, including memories of her adoptive mother Bell-mère, her sister Nojiko, and the eight years of suffering she endured while being forced to work as Arlong's cartographer.
events.significance: This flashback reminds viewers of Nami's trauma and why this conversation with Jinbe is so emotionally charged. It reinforces the personal stakes of the Fish-Man Island arc for Nami.

quotes.text: No matter what, I will never forgive Arlong for what he did.
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami expresses her unshakeable hatred for Arlong despite years passing

events.title: Jinbe Explains Fish-Men and Human Relations
events.description: Jinbe begins to explain the 200-year history of discrimination and hatred between fish-men and humans. He reveals that despite the passage of time, the relationship between the two races has remained unchanged, filled with prejudice and violence.
events.significance: This exposition sets up the central theme of the Fish-Man Island arc: the cycle of hatred and discrimination that has persisted for centuries. It provides crucial context for understanding Arlong's actions and the New Fish-Man Pirates' extremism.

quotes.text: The relationship between fish-men and humans has stayed the same, even over 200 years.
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Jinbe explains the persistent discrimination between the races

events.title: Introduction of Fisher Tiger and Queen Otohime
events.description: Jinbe introduces two legendary figures from Fish-Man Island's history: Fisher Tiger, the hero who freed fish-men slaves from the World Nobles, and Queen Otohime, King Neptune's wife who advocated for peaceful coexistence with humans. These two represented opposing philosophies for achieving fish-men's freedom.
events.significance: This sets up the major flashback arc that will dominate the next several episodes. Fisher Tiger and Queen Otohime are pivotal figures whose actions shaped modern Fish-Man Island and directly influenced characters like Jinbe, Arlong, and Hody Jones.

quotes.text: Two people rose to power to change history: the hero of slaves, Fisher Tiger, and the late queen, Otohime.
quotes.speaker: Jinbe
quotes.context: Jinbe begins the story of Fish-Man Island's most important historical figures

events.title: Nami Notices Similarity Between Arlong Park and Sabaody Park
events.description: Nami recalls seeing the Human Auctioning House at Sabaody Archipelago two years ago and realizes that Arlong Park's design was identical to Sabaody Park, where fish-men and other races were sold as slaves.
events.significance: This observation connects Arlong's oppression of Nami's village to his own trauma. Arlong recreated the place where his people were enslaved, reversing the power dynamic by making humans his prisoners. It adds layers to understanding Arlong's psychology and the cycle of hatred.

quotes.text: From two years ago on Sabaody, I noticed that Sabaody Park is identical to Arlong Park in design.
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami realizes the dark connection between the two parks

events.title: Robin Explores the Sea Forest
events.description: Nico Robin continues her exploration of the Sea Forest, a sacred underwater grove where the Poneglyph of Fish-Man Island is kept. She searches for historical information while the rest of the crew deals with other matters.
events.significance: Robin's dedication to uncovering history leads to the discovery of Joy Boy's message, advancing the series' overarching mysteries about the Void Century.

themes.description: The episode explores how hatred and discrimination perpetuate across generations. The 200-year conflict between fish-men and humans creates extremists on both sides, with victims becoming victimizers.
themes.symbolism: The fumi-e ritual symbolizes how the New Fish-Man Pirates have perverted Otohime's message of peace, forcing citizens to literally step on her ideals.
culturalReferences: Fumi-e was a test of faith used in feudal Japan to identify Christians, where suspected believers were forced to step on images of Jesus or Mary. The same concept is used here to test loyalty to the New Fish-Man Pirates' ideology.

themes.description: Nami must face her painful history with Arlong while seeking answers about why she suffered. This theme extends to Fish-Man Island confronting its own traumatic past.
themes.symbolism: The parallel between Arlong Park and Sabaody Park represents how trauma shapes behavior, with Arlong recreating the site of fish-men's suffering.

themes.description: The episode emphasizes how historical figures like Fisher Tiger and Queen Otohime continue to influence the present through their legacies, for better or worse.
themes.symbolism: Joy Boy's Poneglyph serves as a physical reminder that broken promises echo through centuries.

characterSpotlights.development: Nami confronts her trauma regarding Arlong and seeks understanding of why she suffered. Her emotional journey drives the episode's narrative.

mangaDifferences.difference: In the manga, Hyouzou was only seen forcing citizens to step on Otohime's fumi-e. In the anime, Hyouzou also cuts his gourd after drinking and threatens some citizens who opposed him.
The anime showed Arlong and his childhood companions as full figures in Nami's flashback, while the manga depicted them as silhouettes.

trivia.fact: This is the first episode to use Nami's post-timeskip eyecatcher design.
The fumi-e (踏み絵) ritual shown in this episode is a historical reference to a loyalty test used in feudal Japan to identify Christians, who would be forced to step on images of Jesus or Mary.
This episode marks the first mention of Joy Boy in the One Piece series, a mysterious figure who will become increasingly important to the overarching plot.
Episode 539 adapts Chapter 620 (pages 2-16) of the manga.
